newsitem.title: USA: Echostar says files against News Corp.
newsitem.headline: Echostar says files against News Corp.

text.p: EchoStar Communications Corp said Friday it has filed for a declaratory judgment in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado.
Echostar said in a statement the action seeks a judgment confirming the obligation of News Corp to loan EchoStar $200 million.
EchoStar said it is confident that the court will confirm its position.
News Corp officials were not immediately available for comment.

In February, EchoStar and News Corp announced a direct-TV satellite deal intended to offer as many as 500 channels of digital television, Internet services and local-broadcast TV signals to markets nationwide.

But last week the deal between the two companies seemed to have snagged on a dispute over which conditional-access system would be used. That is the system that allows subscribers to view only those channels they have paid to watch.
EchoStar delayed regulatory filings in regard to the deal, saying News Corp wanted it to abandon its current system in favor of one owned by News Corp.
Then on May 2 came the resignation of Preston Padden, head of News Corp's ASkyB satellite TV service, which created more doubt about the venture among industry analysts.
At the time, News Corp Chairman Rupert Murdoch was quoted in the Wall Street Journal as saying he would go ahead with launching a satellite TV service, with or without EchoStar.
